title: Who will Twitter name as their permanent CEO before the end of the year?
possible_answers: No one will be named CEO before the end of the year
preds: Now I'm sorry that I blinked and went down to 95% on news of Twitter stock falling. Oh, me of little faith.
thank goodness: http://globalnews.ca/news/2258505/jack-dorsey-named-permanent-twitter-ceo/ follow up question should be how many board members survive this debacle.

Well, this confirms that Jack Dorsey is Twitter's new CEO 
http://www.nytimes.com/2015/10/06/technology/twitter-names-jack-dorsey-chief-executive.html?smid=fb-nytimes&smtyp=cur
Twitter needs monetize the traffic, and someone as CEO to do it.

Chris Sacca (Twitter investor), Ryan Sarver (former Twitter Director of Platform) seem to be rooting for Jack Dorsey.  Revenue chief Adam Bain and CFO Anthony Noto seem to have indicated to the board, in recent discussions, that they want Dorsey in the top job as well (re/code, CNBC). According to re/code, the Twitter board also has a “Plan B” of one serious outside candidate, but "every single person contacted (by re/code) who has been seriously considered and also contacted by the company’s recruiting firm, Spencer Stuart, said that their discussions did not progress very far". http://recode.net/2015/09/30/sources-jack-dorsey-to-be-named-permanent-twitter-ceo/ https://twitter.com/rsarver/status/649287689720758272
Twitter’s share price fell by 8.4% on Thursday as rumours swirled about the appointment. https://espresso.economist.com/f2705b6c9182d54c89550489fb10e808?fsrc=scn%2Fesp%2Ftw

Many posts suggest that Jack Dorsey will be named - possibly this next week.

There have been some conflicting news about Jack Dorsey becoming the permanent CEO, it's definitely not settle yet, but it brings up the anxiety from shareholders and it impacts the twitter stock. So it's in board's interest to make that decision soon.
This appears to have been decided, according to late reports.

http://recode.net/2015/09/30/sources-jack-dorsey-to-be-named-permanent-twitter-ceo/
Jack is apparently back — for good this time. Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey, who has been serving as interim CEO for the past three months, is expected to be named the company’s new permanent CEO as early as tomorrow, although that timeframe may change, according to sources. Dorsey will apparently continue to run Square, the payments company he founded where he’s also CEO. Update: Sources said that it’s not clear if the board has officially voted on Dorsey’s appointment, because it was still settling the status of other key execs this week, most specifically revenue chief Adam Bain and CFO Anthony Noto. Bain is widely expected to become COO, although Noto may also report directly to Dorsey. Both have indicated to the board, said multiple sources, that they want Dorsey in the top job. These discussions with them about a new regime started recently.

http://www.lesechos.fr/tech-medias/hightech/021369891759-jack-dorsey-serait-bien-parti-pour-rester-a-la-tete-de-twitter-1161175.php Re/Code announced on its website that J ack Dorsey is the favorite in the run for CEO, and this news was welcomed by the market (+5% on wednesday September 30th).

Moving Jack D up a little, None down a little.   Jack D's supporters are going to the press! http://www.nytimes.com/2015/09/29/technology/momentum-grows-for-jack-dorsey-of-square-to-also-run-twitter.html

Twitter concern: after board announced in July that the new CEO would be fully commited to Twiiter,  there may be a case for investors to make the case that they purchased stock on the expectation that the boards statement was true.
Moving up Adam Bain a bit.  People I respect seem to think he's better than Noto.

If they wanted to name Dorsey, the board would have done so by now.  He's clearly interested in remaining CEO of Square and not is not a good solution.  They need a product guy, the perfect candidate has probably already turned down the position and that's why an insider like Adam Bain will get it.  Anthony Noto is a banker and shouldn't be trusted to run a company.

TWTR likely to name an insider. While Jack is a strong candidate, he can't be the CEO of two companies. As Square is going to file IPO, Jack will stay as its CEO. Anthony Noto is knowledgable and fully committed to the company and has been purchasing TWTR stocks from his personal fund. If no one is named before end of the year, key employees will leave and stock price will drop even further.
If no one is named by year end it's a complete disaster. Dorsey and Bain know the company and by all accounts are well respected by current employees.

Jack Dorsey seems to be a capable for the role, but since he has held the role but left seem to indicate that there are some hesitations maybe from both sides (himself and the board) to keep him in that position.  It's good to pick the CEO as soon as possible  to provide everyone a certainty and allow the company strategically moving forward. With Jack serves as a good interim CEO, it could provide some breathing room for the board and maybe allow them to make decision after the year end.

The reluctance to name Dorsey now as permanent CEO indicates something fundamental about the fit - both from twitter side and from Dorsey's side. While Dorsey was the ultimate product guy when twitter was startup the responsibilities required of CEO at this stage may not fit his interest or passion. Expect someone outside.

http://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/twitter/11891887/adam-bain-interview-twitter-jack-dorsey.html
Keeping Dorsey as the favorite, moving Bain as the second, based on attached link.

Either an outsider is brought in with a "new vision" (boosting equity short term for a re-org and quick sale) or they sell out in the next 9 months. Most likely acquirer - Verizon who puts it under the AOL umbrella and Armstrong "figures it out" by monetizing it's localization potential. Would also make sense for a media company to buy them, but it would be a huge gamble considering the dramatic shifts in that business. My long shot in that scenario - Fox (they gambled on Myspace). It does not make sense for Facebook (don't need 'em), Apple (beats is a bust) or Google.

Stock is down and any internal candidates will have problems breaking CEO stack on the board. Recent external tech hires have been good too.  If they go external it's much more complicated (ie candidate is likely employe now) so they may not finish by eoy
Who cares - they will be gone in 5 years
Twitter has had difficulties recruiting executive management to date. I don't think this pattern will change.
I have no clue. Who cares?  Aligning with crowd.  Better to ask who will be President of Reddit in 6 months or Chairman of the Bitcoin Society.
There is currently pressure on the company, which has not been performing to expectations.  They will name a CEO to reassure investors rather than for intrinsic reasons.

Sacca thinks he will prevail: http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/09/24/twitter-board-hire-jack-dorsey-ceo---sacca/72729160/
but it's already been 100 days...
Dorsey loves his company way too much to give it to some unknown hands

This is an interesting timing-related question. Here are the key points:
- Dorsey is the clear favorite on the board, but is CEO of Square (and the board have explicitly said that they'll only take a full-time candidate here)
- Twitter doesn't appear to be in a rush to find a permanent CEO; the last news was months ago.
- Square has supposedly filed privately for an IPO. That was back in June or July, and there's been no news since. That sort of off the shelf filing apparently allows companies to IPO with short notice at any point for two years after the initial filing, so Square's IPO could happen at any point in time.
- Unresolved: If Square IPOs, wouldn't Dorsey's primary focus be there?
- Unresolved: Is Square also an acquisition candidate (possibly by Twitter?)? Is it also looking for a new CEO? My best guess is that this won't resolve until next year, but I can't take the other options off the table either.
Jack Dorsey is the interim CEO, and is strongly backed by Chris Sacca. Chris has lots of influence, so I think that is the most likely outcome.
Losing too much influence to keep it in-house.

Market turmoil and investor support may give Dorsey the CEO job. http://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/09/24/twitter-board-hire-jack-dorsey-ceo---sacca/72729160/
Billionair? shareholder Sacca says he gets what he wants: says Dorsey will be next CEO. http://americasmarkets.usatoday.com/2015/09/24/twitter-shares-plunge-on-downgrade-ceo-search/
Twitter falls another 5% on Twitter concerns, market reactions may force the issue: Dorsey may be the new CEO:
"SunTrust analyst Robert Peck said in a research note Monday that investors support Dorsey as CEO."
Had to change my percentage allotment. Misunderstood the selections on my first choice.

It looks more likely than not that a CEO will be chosen before the end of the year; the news stories about the search indicate that there is some pressure to find a new CEO quickly.  About a 100 days have passed since the last CEO resigned; if an average of 100 more days pass, then there is about a 35% chance that there will be no CEO before the end of the year. According to a recent Quartz article, "Jack Dorsey—the social network’s cofounder, chairman, former CEO, and current interim CEO—appears to be the top contender" [1].  Adam Bain and Anthony Noto appear to possible, but not incredibly likely, candidates.  My sense that "Someone Else" is more likely than both of them combined. [1] http://qz.com/508417/twitters-board-needs-to-get-over-the-fact-that-jack-dorsey-is-running-two-companies/
Rumors of LinkedIn or another acquisition perhaps not unfounded, some company moves suggest that may be open to a merger.

No clear clues as to the process, which has already dragged on for too long: http://www.valuewalk.com/2015/09/100-days-twitter-ceo-search-still-on/
But the likeliest is still Dorsey.
Will Twitter lose Dorsey, if he is not selected?

These are not children who play together nicely, and none of them seems to understand that Twitter is very close to circling the drain.  All the insiders hate each other, and there is little chance of agreement on an outsider. If they are smart (for which there is little evidence) they'll temporize longer and leave Dorsey in place.

None of the names mentioned have stepped up and the problem is that no one has a clear idea how to monetise Twitter at scale. It will probably take and outsider with a fresh perspective to make the sort of changes needed to bring in the cash.

wow -- complicated. Dorsey wants his Square payday, so i doubt he'd officially take the job.  But who?  If Dorsey wants the CEO job back, he'll just stay on as "interim" -- like another famous "interim" CEO did many years ago.

Most likely they'll punt.  I think they want Jack, but only if he's committed, and Jack doesn't want to quit Square.   As a comparison, Steve Jobs was interim Apple CEO from September 1997 to January 2000 (27 months).  Dorsey's only been interim CEO since July of this year (3 months). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Jobs
OTH is in the lead now so I will mindless reinforce that trend.

http://www.wired.com/2015/09/100-days-later-twitter-still-hasnt-picked-ceo/
http://americasmarkets.usatoday.com/2015/09/21/whats-taking-so-long-twitter-ceo-search-surpasses-100-days/
Both current links advocate for Dorsey. Twitter (quite some time ago) required new CEO to be fully commited to company.  Dorsey has stepped in, and other than leading "Square" as well, looks like a good fit.  Link suspects Twitter may accept Dorsey. Twitter reportedly is losing employees and credibility with advertisers as issues increase, and the wait continues.

A product with continued game-ification potential plus the way many younger people get their "news" (even if incorrect or misleading 25% of the time - but don't believe me ;) )    But how to make $. Suspect more time in wilderness and lower valuation before someone scoops it.

I don't believe a strategic vision can be developed and acted upon before the end of the year. In my mind, watching CNBC commentary over the last few months, the uncertainty, the directional waffling, I think the company will be acquired before a CEO is named. Who would want the job? … except for a Silver Parachute of sorts. Maybe a mid-range VC partner who will work toward a merger/acquisition. Twitter sure does bring value but how to monetize…. they can't figure it out.
